snippet: Though many are eager to hire minorities, well-intended policies that were not meant to discriminate have created obstacles in cities across the nation.
abstract: Police chiefs, like William T Riley III of Inkster, Mich, struggle to diversify their departments, encountering different obstacles from region to region; well-meaning policies sometimes undermine departments' efforts to reflect demographics of communities they serve, goal many believe reduces discrimination; smaller cities with high minority populations often suffer from disparity.

byline.original: By MATT APUZZO and SARAH COHEN
byline.contributor: Matt Apuzzo reported from Inkster, Mich., and Sarah Cohen from New York.

lead_paragraph: Though many are eager to hire minorities, well-intended policies that were not meant to discriminate have created obstacles in cities across the nation.

headline.main: Police Chiefs, Looking to Diversify Forces, Face Structural Hurdles
headline.print_headline: When Police Seek More Diversity, Outside Forces Can Raise Hurdles
